description.plain:
WELCOME TO GENIUS' MARCH 2020 SINGLES RELEASE CALENDAR!!!



For March 2020 album releases, visit this page



This page highlights the notable singles released in all genres throughout March 2020. Each song title includes a hyperlink to the corresponding lyric page.

HOW CAN YOU HELP?


Adding songs



If there’s a notable song you think should be listed here, add it! Or add a comment at the bottom of the page if you’re not sure. No self-promotion, please.


Adding lyrics



If you notice that any of the songs on this list haven’t been transcribed, go to the corresponding page and add in lyrics!


Updating dates



If we have any dates wrong, etc, add a comment at the bottom of the page.

song.embed_content: Read “March 2020 Singles Release Calendar” by Genius on Genius

body.plain:
WELCOME TO GENIUS' MARCH 2020 SINGLES RELEASE CALENDAR!!!



For March 2020 album releases, visit this page



This page highlights the notable singles released in all genres throughout March 2020. Each song title includes a hyperlink to the corresponding lyric page.

HOW CAN YOU HELP?


Adding songs



If there’s a notable song you think should be listed here, add it! Or add a comment at the bottom of the page if you’re not sure. No self-promotion, please.


Adding lyrics



If you notice that any of the songs on this list haven’t been transcribed, go to the corresponding page and add in lyrics!


Updating dates



If we have any dates wrong, etc, add a comment at the bottom of the page.

search_results.title: Lilacs
search_results.lyrics:
Lilacs Lyrics[Intro]
One, two, three, four

[Verse 1]
I wake up feeling nothing, camouflage the wavering sky
I sit at my piano, wander the wild whereby
And the lilacs drank the water, and the lilacs die
And the lilacs drank the water, marking the slow, slow
Slow passing of time

[Verse 2]
I get so angry, baby, at something you might say
I dream about an awful stranger, work my way through the day
I run it like a silent movie, I run it like a violent song
Run it like a voice compelling, so right it can't be wrong
[Chorus]
If I'm a broken record, write it in the dust, babe
I'll fill myself back up like I used to do
And if my bones are made of delicate sugar
I won't end up anywhere good without you, ooh
I need your love too

[Verse 3]
When I live a sparse existence, I'll drop down in the fold
Lean in to an urgent falter, spin silence into gold
I run it like the crop of kismet, I run it like a dilettante
I run it like I'm happy, baby, like I got everything I want

[Chorus]
If I'm a broken record, write it in the dust, babe
I'll fill myself back up like I used to do
And if my bones are made of delicate sugar
I won't end up anywhere good without you
I won't end up anywhere good without you, ooh
I need your love too

[Outro]
And the lilacs drank the water
And the lilacs drank the water
And the lilacs drank the waterSee Waxahatchee LiveGet tickets as low as $32You might also like2Embed

description.plain: “Lilacs,” the fourth track off Saint Cloud (2020), is a song about needing someone’s love, and being angry about it. It was described by Katie as “a reminder that none of us are ever done doing work.”

song.embed_content: Read “Lilacs” by Waxahatchee on Genius
song.title: Lilacs

body.plain: “Lilacs,” the fourth track off Saint Cloud (2020), is a song about needing someone’s love, and being angry about it. It was described by Katie as “a reminder that none of us are ever done doing work.”

annotations:
And the lilacs drank the water, marking the slow, slow
 Slow passing of time

The music nicely mirrors the lyrics in this line. The third repetition of “slow” comes on the first beat of the next measure, where you’d naturally expect the phrase to resolve. Instead, the resolution (“passing of time”) comes a beat late — illustrating the slow passage of time.
I wake up feeling nothing, camouflage the wavering sky
This opening line introduces the theme of depression: the phrase “camouflage the wavering sky” refers to the feeling blue, i.e. depressed.
I get so angry, baby, at something you might say
Crutchfield knows this person so well that she can almost predict what spite or bitterness they may try to convey, and can read his/her thoughts based on their expressions/moods.
Dilettante
A dilettante is a person who thinks they know a lot about a subject, but doesn’t really have any expertise.
I won’t end up anywhere good without you, ooh
This is qualified by the previous line.  If she were delicate and fragile, then she would be dependent on someone else to get her to a good place.
And the lilacs drank the water, and the lilacs die

Too much of a good thing can kill you.  In this song, the metaphor of a lilac being overwatered stands in for the narrator striving for self dependence with a partner/friend.  When the lilac drinks the water, the lilac dies.  When Katie is too dependent on external affirmation, she ends up no where good.

It's not as if we cry a river, call it rain
West Memphis is on fire in the light of day
Give me something, it ain't enough
It ain't enough

description.plain:
“Fire” is a song about the difficulty of loving yourself unconditionally and described it as “my higher self singing to my inner child, or my lower self.”
As stated by the artist in a Rolling Stone interview, “Fire” was the first time she has “written a large portion of a song not at an instrument or at a piece of paper.”

song.embed_content: Read “Fire” by Waxahatchee on Genius
song.title: Fire

body.plain:
“Fire” is a song about the difficulty of loving yourself unconditionally and described it as “my higher self singing to my inner child, or my lower self.”
As stated by the artist in a Rolling Stone interview, “Fire” was the first time she has “written a large portion of a song not at an instrument or at a piece of paper.”

annotations:
And when I turn back around
 Will you drain me back out?
 Will you let me believe that I broke through?

In the Pitchfork review, these lines are cited as being about Crutchfield’s previous tendency to “promise to make [herself] meek, small as a bird, even turn into liquid, just to live inside someone.” This might be the case, but given that Crutchfield has said this is a song to herself, it could also be her worrying that all of the progress she’s made might dissipate. Progress isn’t a straight line, and it’s easy to feel, in moments, that all of the work you’ve done on yourself has been for naught; we want to believe that we’ve had these breakthroughs and nothing will look quite the same again, but then we find ourselves falling back into old patterns. These lines could well be her grappling with this.

If I could love you unconditionally
 I could iron out the edges of the darkest sky

The “you” in this song, as Katie acknowledged in her interview with Pitchfork, is herself. She’s saying that if she could love herself unconditionally, she would be unstoppable, and able to quell her moments of darkness more easily.
That’s what I wanted

It’s about getting to a more grounded, centered, self-assured place. Just recognizing the low points and the hard moments. Even though I’m having this moment of reckoning with myself, I do have to remind myself that I’ve made a lot of progress, and it is getting easier. That’s what I wanted, for it to get easier.

– Katie Crutchfield, Pitchfork

It’s not as if we cry a river, call it rain
 West Memphis is on fire in the light of day

Calling a river of tears rain would be understating the pain that those tears stem from. Rain suggests impermanence, while a river runs indefinitely.

Following up this line with the statement that West Memphis is “on fire in the light of day,” a connection is made to the aforementioned rain. The metaphor between the fire and pain could be put out by rain, but not a river. A quick cry over something less important could put out the fire of what was being cried over. As the river of tears flows, however, the fire burns beside it.

I’m a bird in the trees
 I can learn to see with a partial view

The narrator wants to see her life both from above, and without feeling like she needs to see the whole picture.  The narrator is learning to take a limited perspective, and one without needing full understanding as a mechanism for accepting herself.
Give me something, it ain’t enough

This is an acknowledgement that what she gets from the people around her isn’t enough to fill her up.  She may continually ask for affirmation and attention and love, but she knows that genuine acceptance doesn’t come externally.

search_results.title: Take Me Home, Country Roads
search_results.title_with_featured: Take Me Home, Country Roads (Ft. Waxahatchee)
search_results.lyrics:
Take Me Home, Country Roads Lyrics[Verse 1]
Almost heaven, West Virginia
Blue Ridge Mountains, Shenandoah River
Life is old there, older than the trees
Younger than the mountains, growing like a breeze

[Chorus]
Country roads, take me home
To the place I belong
West Virginia, mountain mamma
Take me home, country roads
[Verse 2]
All my memories gather 'round her
Miner's lady, stranger to blue water
Dark and dusty, painted on the sky
Misty taste of moonshine, teardrops in my eyes

[Chorus]
Country roads, take me home
To the place I belong
West Virginia, mountain mamma
Take me home, country roads

[Bridge]
I hear her voice in the morning hour she calls me
The radio reminds me of my home far away
Driving down the road I get a feeling
That I should have been home yesterday, yesterday

[Chorus]
Country roads, take me home
To the place I belong
West Virginia, mountain mamma
Take me home, country roads
Country roads, take me home
To the place I belong
West Virginia, mountain mamma
Take me home, country roads
You might also like[Outro]
Take me home, (Down) country roads
Take me home, (Down) country roadsEmbed

description.plain: Whitney’s very faithful take on John Denver’s folk classic, reimagined as a duet with indie rock and folk artist Waxahatchee.

Can’t Do Much Lyrics[Verse 1]
We will coalesce our heaven and hell
My eyes roll around like dice on the felt
My mind turns to something useless and trite
My uneasiness, materialized

[Chorus]
I want you
All the time
Sanity
Nullified
[Verse 2]
When you're missing me, oh, what do you see?
Something wild that you think you'll never be?
Something safe that you could tend to and leave?
Something versatile to fill all your needs?
Maybe

[Refrain]
I give it to you all on a dime
I love you 'til the day I—
Love you 'til the day I—
Love you 'til the day I—
Love you 'til the day I die
I guess it don't matter why

In my loneliness, I'm locked in a room
When you see me, I'm honey on a spoon
Do you think that you were reading my mind?
My uneasiness materialized

[Chorus]
I'm waiting
All the time
Sanity
Nullified

description.plain: The first line  gestures toward William Blake’s The Marriage of Heaven and Hell, where Blake argues that desire is part of us and the cosmic order and not some kind of satanic otherness. As this song is about desire and fellow-travelling anxiety, the allusion is apt and a good way to kick things off.

song.embed_content: Read “Can't Do Much” by Waxahatchee on Genius
song.title: Can’t Do Much

body.plain: The first line  gestures toward William Blake’s The Marriage of Heaven and Hell, where Blake argues that desire is part of us and the cosmic order and not some kind of satanic otherness. As this song is about desire and fellow-travelling anxiety, the allusion is apt and a good way to kick things off.

annotations: My eyes roll around like dice on the felt
Here Waxahatchee invokes gambling imagery, implying she is gambling her heart and not winning.

A little too long a walk out to La Grange

You'll be thirsty for a glass of lemonade
Try to slow down and hang around
Along the way

Could you pick a better place to lose some change?
Down in Kemah it might seem

song.embed_content: Read “Corsicana Lemonade” by White Denim on Genius
song.title: Corsicana Lemonade

annotations:
Down in Kemah it might seem
 A little too long a walk out to La Grange
LaGrange is about 130 miles to the west of Kemah.
Nacogdoches up to Lucas
This is about a three-hour trip north. Somewhere between 180 and 190 miles on the highway.

search_results.full_title: Fruits of My Labor by Waxahatchee

search_results.lyrics:
Fruits of My Labor LyricsBaby, see how I been living
Velvet curtains on the windows to
See the bright and unforgiving
Light from shining through

Babe, I remember all the things we did
When we slept together
In the blue behind your eyelids
Baby, sweet baby

I traced your scent through the gloom
'Til I found these purple flowers
I was spent, I was soon
Smelling you for hours
Lavender, lotus blossoms too
Water the dirt, flowers last for you
Baby, sweet baby

Tangerines and persimmons
And sugarcane
Grapes and honeydew melon
Enough fit for a queen

Lеmon trees don't make a sound
'Til branches bend and fruit falls to thе ground
Baby, sweet baby

Oh, come to my world and witness
The way things have changed
'Cause I finally did it, babe
I got out of La Grange

I got in my Mercury and drove out west
Pedal to the metal and my luck to the test
Baby, sweet baby

I been tryin' to enjoy all the fruits of my labor
I been cryin' for you boy but truth is my savior

Baby, sweet baby if it's all the same
Take the glory any day over the fame

description.plain: On the one-year anniversary of Saint Cloud’s release, Waxahatchee released a deluxe version featuring three cover songs, including “Fruits of My Labor” by Lucinda Williams. This version was recorded during the Saint Cloud album recording sessions.
